items.description: Wyre estuary from Fleetwood and Knott End to Little Eccleston
Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water
items.message:
Water levels are remaining high on the Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water. 
Further rainfall is forecast throughout Tuesday (27/12/2022) afternoon and early evening and again on Wednesday (28/12/2022). No property flooding is expected, and we do not expect to issue a Flood Warning at this time.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 11:59 AM on 28/12/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Humber estuary from Spurn Point to Winestead Outfall
items.message: The flood forecast has changed significantly. As a result, there is no longer a risk of flooding in the area.

items.description: North Sea coast at Withernsea, Easington and Kilnsea
items.message: The flood forecast has changed significantly. As a result, there is no longer a risk of flooding in the area.

items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
Wednesday afternoon's tide at 12:00 noon is higher than normal due to unsettled weather with westerly force 8 winds and large waves.
Areas most at risk include Christchurch Harbour and tidal stretches of the Lower Stour and Avon.
Highest tide level is expected to be at Christchurch Harbour and tidal stretches of the Lower Stour and Avon at 12:00 noon on 28/12/2022. Flooding is possible 2 hours either side of this time.
After this tide‚ the weather is more settled and no further impacts are expected.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.
Consider activating any property flood protection products in Christchurch Harbour.
We will remove this message by 03:00 PM on 28/12/2022.

floodArea.county: Bournemouth, Christchurch and Poole, Dorset Council

items.message:
Wednesday morning's tide at 10:15 AM is higher than normal due to unsettled weather with southerly force 7 winds and large waves.
Areas most at risk include Castletown, Weymouth and Preston Beach.
After this tide‚ the weather is more settled and no further impacts are expected.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.
Plan driving routes to coastal roads, which may be flooded.
Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
We will remove this message by 01:00 PM on 28/12/2022.

Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels remain high but steady on the River Wey as a result of previous heavy rainfall. Further rainfall is forecast over night and into tomorrow 28/12/22. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' web page for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 28/12/22, or as the situation changes.

River levels are forecast to rise at the Pillings Lock river gauge.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible to begin between 18:00 and 19:00 today, 27/12/22.  Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Slash Lane at Sileby and the Mountsorrel to Sileby road.   
Further light rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours.  We expect river levels to rise until the evening of the 29/12/22.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  This message will be updated by 9:00 on 28/12/22, or as the situation changes.
Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated "

floodArea.county: Bath and North East Somerset, Wiltshire

items.message: River levels at the Bradford on Avon river gauge are falling but remain high. Consequently, the risk of flooding remains. Expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads between Melksham and Bathford. The flood gates at Holt Road may be closed. Further rainfall, sometimes heavy, is expected from this afternoon, Tuesday 27/12/2022 and on Wednesday 28/12/2022. River levels are expected to rise again in response to this rainfall. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are clearing weed screens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded. Refer to local authority website for local road closures. This message will be updated by 14:00 on Wednesday, 28/12/22, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Bracknell Forest, Surrey, Windsor and Maidenhead

items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are high but steady on the Chertsey Bourne as a result of heavy rainfall. Further rainfall is forecast overnight and into tomorrow 28/12/22. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 28/12/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: South Devon coast from Start Point to Dawlish Warren
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible over the high tide on Wednesday morning. High water at Dartmouth is at 9:45am. Times of high water will vary along the coast.
The forecast of strong winds suggests possible impact from wave action although no property flooding is expected.  People are advised to stay away from risk areas and take care next to the coast. 

Detailed tidal information for those who use it; the forecast high tide level for Wednesday is 2.32m at Dartmouth, this is 0.35 metres above the astronomical tide level.
We will continue to monitor the tidal forecast and update the situation as required.

items.description: River Trent from Cromwell Weir to Gainsborough
items.message: This Flood Alert has been removed.  River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.   We continue to monitor the situation.

Wednesday afternoon's tide at 14:30 on 28/12/2022 is higher than normal due to unsettled weather with strong South Westerly Force 7 winds and large waves. The weather increases tide table values by 0.58 m. The total forecast tide is 4.70 metres Chart Datum (2.11 mAOD) at Cowes. For 1 hour either side of high water, large waves will cause spray overtopping and overwashing of defences across the exposed coast at Freshwater Bay, Sandown, Shanklin, Gurnard and Ryde. This will flood sea front esplanades, car parks and roads. As Cowes is largely sheltered from the waves, impacts will be more minimal. We do not expect property flooding. At 03:45 on 29/12/2022, as wave heights remain elevated, some minor impact spray overtopping affecting the southern coastal frontage may continue. After this time, no further impacts are expected. We continue to monitor the forecast. At high tide, avoid parking, walking or driving at exposed sea front locations. We will remove this message by 18:00 on 28/12/2022.

items.description: South East Somerset Rivers, Upper Reaches

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Yeo, River Cam, River Wriggle, Barwick Stream, West Coker Stream

items.message: Water levels remain high at the Sherborne Lake river gauge as a result of recent heavy rainfall. Consequently, there is a low risk of flooding to low-lying land and roads today, Tuesday, 27/12/22. Locations most vulnerable to flooding are the Sparkford to Weston Bampfylde road and Deep Ford Lane, Chetnole. Further showery rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours. River levels are slowly falling, we expect levels to remain high over the next 24 hours. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low-lying footpaths and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers which may be flooded. Please refer to local authority website for local road closures. This message will be updated by 12:00 on Wednesday, 28/11/22, or as the situation changes

items.description: The tidal River Yare from Thorpe St Andrew to Breydon Water
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely to continue today, Tuesday 27th December, and overnight into Wednesday 28th December. High water levels may last for a few days, until the high tides at Great Yarmouth have passed. We expect to see high water levels in Brundall and Reedham riverside areas. We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message by 9am tomorrow, Wednesday 28th December.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Tamar, River Strat, River Neet, River Ottery, River Kensey

items.message:
Flooding is possible this evening (Tuesday 27th December) and overnight into Wednesday 28th December. Over the last several hours we have seen persistent rainfall on wet ground. As a result, the river Tamar is now rising. Expected levels suggest that there will be flooding to low lying land and roads, peaking at Tamarstone and Crowford Bridge during Tuesday evening. We expect the river to remain high throughout Wednesday. 
Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions. We are monitoring river levels and have staff in the area checking for and clearing blockages. This message will be updated on Wednesday morning or earlier if the situation changes.

Wednesday afternoon's tide at 15:15 on 28/12/22 is higher than normal due to unsettled weather with Gale Force 8 South Westerly winds and large waves. The weather increases tide table values by 0.42m. The total forecast tide is 5.95 metres Chart Datum (2.90 mAOD) at Littlehampton. For 2 hours either side of high tide small amounts of water will flood land and fields at Climping. Waves will overtop the sea front, directing water westwards along Mill Lane from the right of the East car park, towards properties on Climping Street. Water may pond near property and in Climping Street Car Park. Large waves, a similarly high tide and minor flood impacts are forecast early Thursday morning too. Waves will remain large all week but flood risk should reduce as tides fall by Friday. We continue to monitor the forecast and routinely check the condition of the beach at Climping. Shingle and debris can be thrown by large waves. Avoid walking at the sea front or parking at Climping Street Car Park. Access could be restricted during and after high tide. We will update this message by 19:00 28/12/22.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible on Tuesday evening and into Wednesday.
Throughout Tuesday afternoon heavy rainfall has been falling in the Dartmoor area and is forecast to continue for the next couple of days. This will cause water levels in the River Dart and its tributaries to rise. 
Flooding to low lying land and roads is expected. 
We expect the rivers to remain high throughout the early part of this week and will remain sensitive to further rainfall.  We may issue Flood Warnings as necessary.
Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions. We are constantly monitoring river levels and will have staff in the area checking for and clearing blockages. This message will be updated on the afternoon of Wednesday 28 December 2022 or earlier if the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Teign, River Bovey, River Lemon, River Kenn

items.message:
Flooding is possible on Tuesday evening and into Wednesday.
Throughout Tuesday afternoon heavy rainfall has been falling in the Dartmoor area and is forecast to continue for the next couple of days. This will cause water levels in the River Teign to rise. 
Flooding to low lying land and roads is expected and we also expect the rivers to remain high throughout the early part of this week and will remain sensitive to further rainfall.  We may issue Flood Warnings as necessary.
Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions. We are constantly monitoring river levels and will have staff in the area checking for and clearing blockages. This message will be updated on the afternoon of Wednesday 28 December 2022, or earlier if the situation changes.

River levels are rising on the Upper River Ure and its tributaries due to recent heavy rainfall. Flooding is forecast to affect low lying land, particularly around the River Ure and tributaries from its source downstream to Kilgram. Further rainfall is forecast throughout this evening, Tuesday 27/12/2022, and river levels are expected to remain high overnight. We are monitoring rainfall and will continue to monitor river levels closely. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated within 8 hours, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high at the Lugwardine river gauge following recent heavy rainfall. Flooding continues. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the River Lugg south of Leominster from Stoke Prior to Mordiford. Other locations that may be affected include Bodenham, Lugwardine and Hampton Bishop. We expect river levels to remain elevated for the next few days and potentially impacted by additional rainfall forecast for later today, 27/12/22, and tomorrow, 28/12/22. Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid contact with flood water. This message will be updated by midday on 28/12/22, or as the situation changes.

This Flood Alert has been removed. River levels have below the flood risk threshold. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert/warning if necessary. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels.

River levels at the Great Somerford river gauge are falling but remain high. Consequently, the risk of flooding remains. We expect flooding to affect the road at Reybridge. Further rainfall, sometimes heavy, is expected from this afternoon, Tuesday 27/12/2022 and on Wednesday 28/12/2022. River levels are expected to rise again in response to this rainfall. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are clearing weed screens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded. Refer to local authority website for local road closures. This message will be updated by 14:00 on Wednesday, 28/12/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Yeo and River Parrett Moors around Muchelney and Thorney
items.message: The River Yeo level at Huish Episcopi pumping station is 8.027 m and is falling by approximately 13 mm per hour. The drain level at Huish Episcopi pumping station is 7.25 m and is falling by approximately 6.5 mm per hour. Flooding will affect the road from Langport to Muchelney if this level exceeds 7.3 m, the road from Muchelney to Long load if this level exceeds 7.86 and the road from Muchelney to Thorney if this level exceeds 7.93 m. Property flooding is possible if this level exceeds 8.35 m. Unsettled weather is forecast for the next 48hrs. The River Yeo at Muchelney is forecast to remain stable as a result.

River levels are forecast to rise on the Lower Dorset Frome due to forecast heavy rainfall this afternoon and overnight.
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Lower Dorset Frome, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around tributaries between Dorchester and Wareham.
Further rainfall is forecast overnight and into tomorrow.
River levels are high and forecast to rise further.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 11:00 AM on 28/12/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Avon, River Erme, River Harbourne

items.message:
Flooding is possible on Tuesday evening and into Wednesday.
Throughout Tuesday afternoon heavy rainfall has been falling in the Dartmoor area and is forecast to continue for the next couple of days. This will cause water levels in the Rivers Harbourne, Avon and Erme to rise. 
Flooding to low lying land and roads is expected. 
We expect the rivers to remain high throughout the early part of this week and will remain sensitive to further rainfall.  We may issue Flood Warnings as necessary.
Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions. We are constantly monitoring river levels and will have staff in the area checking for and clearing blockages. This message will be updated on the afternoon of Wednesday 28 December 2022 or earlier if the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible from the early hours on Wednesday 28th December.
There has been persistent rainfall over the past 6 hours as two bands of rain move across Cornwall today and overnight, accompanied by strong winds. Rainfall totals are expected to exceed 40mm in 12 hours over high ground.
Catchments are wet and the River Yealm is forecast to react to this rainfall. Expected levels suggest there will be flooding to low lying land and roads close to the river from approximately 6am on Wednesday morning.
Rain is forecast to clear the area on Wednesday afternoon and be followed by scattered showers. The river is expected to remain high throughout Wednesday, though no flooding to properties is currently forecast. The next frontal system is likely to move in on Friday.
Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions. We are monitoring river levels and have staff in the area checking for and clearing blockages. This message will be updated on Wednesday morning or earlier if the situation changes.

This Flood Alert has been removed. River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert/warning if necessary. Please refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels.

The River Tone level at Currymoor pumping station is 7.36 m and is falling by 7.5 mm per hour. Water will enter Currymoor reservoir via Hookbridge spillway whilst this level exceeds 7.45 m. The drain level at Currymoor pumping station is 5.51 m and is falling by approximately 5 mm per hour. There is a risk of water overtopping Haymoor flood storage area and affecting Curload and Stan Moor if this level reaches 8.30 m. Unsettled weather is forecast for the next 48 hours. The River Tone at Currymoor is forecast to rise as a result.

Over the last 24 hours we have seen heavy rainfall in the River Witham area and we are expecting further rainfall tonight (27th of December) and tomorrow (28th of December). This means that the River Witham is expected to rise overnight and into tomorrow, which could lead to flooding of low lying land and roads close to the river from this evening on Tuesday, 27th of December onwards. Therefore we have decided to issue the Flood Alert during sociable hours. We expect the river to remain high throughout the next few days. Our forecasts indicate that flooding to properties isn't likely and therefore flood warnings are not expected to be issued. We are constantly monitoring river levels, and have staff in the field checking for blockages and clearing weedscreens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by midday tomorrow, 28th December, or as the situation changes.

items.message: Over the last 24 hours we have seen heavy rainfall in the River Glens area and we are expecting further rainfall tonight (27th of December) and tomorrow (28th of December). This means that the River Glens are expected to rise overnight and into tomorrow, which could lead to flooding of low lying land and roads close to the river from this evening on Tuesday, 27th of December, onwards. Therefore, we are issuing this Flood Alert during sociable hours. We expect the river to remain high throughout the next few days. Our forecasts indicate that flooding to properties isn't likely and therefore flood warnings are not expected to be issued. We are constantly monitoring river levels, and have staff in the field checking for  blockages and clearing weedscreens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by midday tomorrow, 28th of December, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Cherwell from Lower Heyford down to and including Oxford

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Cherwell, Woodeaton Brook, Bayswater Brook, Marston Brook, Peasmoor Brook

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels are high but gradually falling on the Lower Cherwell as a result of recent rainfall. Therefore, flooding of roads and low lying land is expected to continue today, 27/12/2022, especially in the areas around Thrupp. 
There is further rain forecast this evening, 27/12/2022, which should clear overnight. Further rain is forecast for Wednesday. We expect river levels to continue to fall slowly over the next few days, but the river will remain sensitive to further rainfall.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels and avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. 
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 28/12/2022, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Bournemouth, Christchurch and Poole, Dorset Council, Hampshire

items.message:
River levels are high and forecast to rise further on the Middle and Lower Hampshire Avon due to forecast heavy rainfall this afternoon and into tomorrow.
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Middle and Lower Hampshire Avon, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around tributaries between Ringwood and Christchurch. Further rainfall is forecast overnight and into tomorrow.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 11:00 AM on 28/12/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels are high but steady on the River Ray as a result of recent rainfall. Therefore, flooding of roads and low lying land is expected to continue today, 27/12/2022, especially in the areas around Islip. 
There is further rain forecast this evening, 27/12/2022, which should clear overnight. Further rain is forecast for Wednesday. We expect river levels to begin to fall slowly over the next few days but the river will remain sensitive to further rainfall.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels and avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. 
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 28/12/2022, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high but steady at the Brimscombe river gauge as a result of recent rainfall, consequently flooding of roads and farmland may continue. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from Elmore to Sharpness. Other locations that may be affected include Chalford, Leonard Stanley and Cambridge. We expect river levels to remain elevated for the next few days and potentially impacted by additional rainfall forecast for later today, 27/12/22, and tomorrow, 28/12/22. This message will be updated by 12:00pm on 28/12/22 or as the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible this evening during Tuesday 27th December and overnight into Wednesday 28th December. Over the last several hours we have seen persistent rainfall on wet ground. As a result, the river Lynher is now rising. Expected levels suggest that there will be flooding to low lying land and roads, peaking at Pillaton at approximately 6am on Wednesday 28th December. We expect the river to remain high throughout Wednesday. 
Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions. We are monitoring river levels and have staff in the area checking for and clearing blockages. This message will be updated on Wednesday morning or earlier if the situation changes.

River levels are high and forecast to rise further on the River Piddle due to forecast heavy rainfall this afternoon.
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Piddle, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around tributaries between Alton Pancras and Wareham.
Further rainfall is forecast overnight and into tomorrow.
River levels are high and forecast to rise further.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.

items.description: River Thames and tributaries in the Oxford area
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels have risen on the River Thames as a result of recent rainfall. This alert has been issued due to elevated river levels around Sandford. This message will not be updated, but river levels may rise further and come out of banks. Please take care when walking along the Thames Path and check River Levels online for current levels at Kings Lock, Godstow Lock, Osney Lock, Iffly Lock, Minns Estate and Cold Harbour.
 
We are temporarily automating our messages due to industrial action.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Hayle, Perrancoombe Stream, Bolingey Stream, River Cober, Portreath Stream

items.message:
Flooding is possible from the early hours on Wednesday 28th December.
There has been persistent rainfall over the past 6 hours as two bands of rain move across Cornwall today and overnight, accompanied by strong winds. Rainfall totals are expected to exceed 40mm in 12 hours over high ground.
Catchments are wet and rivers will react to very little rainfall. Forecast levels suggest there will be flooding to low lying land and roads close to rivers from approximately 6am on Wednesday morning.
Rain is forecast to clear the area on Wednesday afternoon and be followed by scattered showers. Rivers are expected to remain high throughout Wednesday and into Thursday. Flood Warnings may be issued if required. The next frontal system is likely to move in on Friday.
Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions. We are monitoring river levels and have staff in the area checking for and clearing blockages. This message will be updated on Wednesday morning or earlier if the situation changes.

items.description: The tidal Rivers Bure, Ant and Thurne
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely this afternoon, Tuesday 27th December and overnight in to Wednesday 28th December. Water levels are expected to continue to rise gradually over the next few hours in response to forecast rainfall, together with the natural tide locking effect on the Broads. We expect to see high water levels around Potter Heigham, Wroxham boat yards and Ferry Road in Horning. We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message by 9am tomorrow, Wednesday 28th December.
